title: 114_hr2233
content: The Act is titled the "End Warrantless Surveillance of Americans Act" and clarifies the prohibition on warrantless searching of collections of communications for the communications of United States persons. Section 702(b) of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to clarify the prohibition on searching collections of communications of United States persons without a warrant. States may search a collection of communications acquired under this section to find communications of a specific United States person, with exceptions for emergency situations. The entity conducting the search must have a reasonable belief that the life or safety of the United States person is at risk, or the person has consented to the search. PROHIBITION ON WARRANTLESS SEARCHING OF COLLECTIONS OF COMMUNICATIONS COLLECTED UNDER EXECUTIVE ORDER FOR THE COMMUNICATIONS OF UNITED STATES PERSONS. The Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2015 prohibits warrantless searching of collections of communications of United States persons, with an exception for emergency situations. The Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2015 prohibits warrantless searching of collections of communications of United States persons, except in emergency situations where the life or safety of the person is threatened. The Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2015 prohibits warrantless searching of collections of communications of United States persons, except in emergency situations where consent is given. Amendments include adding subparagraph (C) to Section 309(b)(3)(A). SEC. 4 of the Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2015 prohibits agencies from mandating surveillance capabilities in products or services, except under the Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act. The term "agency" is defined as per section 3502 of title 44, and "covered product" includes computer hardware, software, or electronic devices available to the public.
